919866355947581441.text: TL;DR on the KRACK WPA2 stuff - you can repeatedly resend the 3rd packet in a WPA2 handshake and it'll reset the key state, which leads to nonce reuse, which leads to trivial decryption with known plaintext. Can be easily leveraged to dump TCP SYN traffic and hijack connections.

Is infosec your career? Then riddle me this, Batman - how many of my best customers have come from DEF CON and other “technical” talks? 

ZERO.

RSA and more business-focused talks?

SHIT TONS.

Priorities. Get them. 

Out. 5/5

958453432934903810.text:
This industry needs to stop obsessing about cons and talks. Here’s an insight for you: as I’ve gone to less cons, I’ve made MORE money. The less technical I try to be (because THAT matters, eye roll), the more my career has flourished. 

Research != con talks. And vice versa. 4/n

958452315241025536.text:
I have seen 1 panel that mattered at all. And even that was mediocre. If you found a bug in a thing, newsflash: 99.9% likelihood your talk matters for shit. “Matters”. As in, really changed security.

Somewhat interesting, maybe. Like a “Seinfeld” rerun level of interesting. 3/n

958451605690515457.text:
It seems like a weird cultural thing, honestly. Like, you get less “respect” in this warped field if you haven’t submitted talks to cons.

Who gives a fuck? Does it really change your trajectory? Earning potential? List of “friends”? 2/n

958451156900073472.text:
Love seeing all this discussion on cons & submitting talks to them. What is the motivation? Do you REALLY need to share your insights? Or is it for the 60 min of “fame”? And some personal brand exposure?

I won’t lie-I’ve only seen 3 talks or so that changed the game for me. 1/n
